title: Suggestion for Windows
comment: I made an app like this one for phones only. Not very popular :). But what I wanted to say is you don't need a driver to draw through the tablet. It's just a matter of sending mouse/key input to the window and adding the capability to define key combinations and keystrokes to suit different windows applications. Just don't use UDP.
And how would you transmit pressure data... Windows 7 does not have any pressure api... Pressure transmission is one of the key points of this app...

title: Very good... but not easy to get working
comment: Getting this to work took me two attempts and several hours of googling. Once I did get it working however, it works superbly. Even better than my wacom intuos in fact. For other people struggling; I did the following to get it working on Xubuntu.  1. Run a terminal window from the folder named 'driver-uinput' then type 'make' and hit enter to compile the binary.  2. In the same terminal window type 'sudo ./networktablet' and hit enter. Confirm any password and the gfxTablet client should begin running.  3. To find your network host ID for the android app, open another terminal, type '/sbin/ifconfig eth0' and hit enter. Your network host ID is the one called 'inet addr'. Enter this in the app settings. In response to the developers snarky comments about 1 star reviews. Instead of being so defensive, perhaps taking heed of the reasons people are leaving those reviews and doing something about it might make people more inclined to donate to or pay you for your work e.g. making the install instructions a little more accessible to the average user.
Why should we do more work for a free, proof-of-concept fun app that does NOT bring us any money? For more motivating 1 star ratings?

Thank you for your valueable feedback and good rating. Please keep in mind that GfxTablet including the protocol is free and open-source, so if you want to improve it, please feel free to make your changes and publish them. You may also have writing permission for the repository.

title: Awesome 5/5

title: Excellent.
comment: Works nicely for Galaxy Note 8. This app saved me the trouble of having to go out and buy an expensive Wacom tablet. Basically, it's worth the download.   I've only had it for a day, but I made a few observations. First of all, the cursor gets glitchy when moving the cursor near the screen's edges. However, this is a very minor detail, since most of the movements are done in the center of the screen anyways. I'm just nitpicking at this point.  The fact that it only works with Linux bothered me at first, but eventually I just decided to do some research and set my computer (Windows 7) up to multi-boot with Linux. Learning how to set up the app in the terminal was a bit confusing, but I got it eventually.   The only thing keeping this app from having five stars is the fact that the majority of people want something they can download and use right away - partitioning, multi-booting, compiling, etc. can seem daunting to the inexperienced user, like me.  Overall, four stars for making me spend a whole day's worth of research just to install this app :p though it was a very rewarding experience. I'm glad I found this.

Thanks for your suggestion. Unfortunately, we don't use Windows ourselves. Why don't you just use Linux? You can even use it within a Virtual Machine while staying with Windows as your operating system. However, if somebody makes a Windows driver, we will of course take it into the repository.

title: Works great and simple!
comment: This is exactly what I was looking for, and I was dreading doing the research and writing the driver myself... I love how simple the desktop server is! Great job!

title: Simple and excellent
comment: Thank you very much devs, I'm not a pro designer but this is perfect for my needs. Much kudos.The only humanly possible Upgrade to this would be the ability to use the blue tooth Stack. big thank you! I use dual monitors and by default x uses both screens as the draw area, to fix this: - Get the input device number using “xinput --list” - get the output device you want to use through “xrandr” - set map using “xinput --map-to-output [input device ID] [output device name]  Please add this information in to your app from a menu, it would make life easier for thos not familiar with nix

title: Excellent!
comment: The app is simple, easy to use, and functions perfectly! The uinput driver runs fine on Arch Linux, and gave me no issues what so ever. Once connected, the app inputs to programs, such as gimp, excellently. It recognizes multiple finger inputs, and pressures. All in all, a very good system, and well done to have it run on Linux!
Brilliant

title: Very considerate
comment: As an old school graphic artist, I have waited for most of my life for technology to grow into my needs. This app is an amazing and thoughtful example of what is needed.  Hopefully more people will grow beyond the restrictions of MS and Apple and begin supporting such development more.  Somewhere a young and creative mind with limited resources is growing because of the time and effort you spent making this.  On behalf of human progress, I Thank you.
Thank you very much for your kind words!

title: Best best best!!
comment: Best app in the whole world...

title: Awesome!
comment: Worked great out of the box with a Nexus 10 on Jelly Bean and Ubuntu 13.04 x64.  Thanks for the excellent app (and server component!)

title: Needs to work on Windows
comment: Please find someone with the skills to develop a driver for windows! Other than that, this is a cool idea and I'm definitely donating.

title: Works very well on Note 10.1
comment: Using Ubuntu and Mypaint. No need to buy a Wacom tablet.

title: Stylus
comment: Hi there, I think this is a great app.  Will any active stylus works?  how do i decide which stylus to buy? i'm using a samsung S4, but i'll be getting a tablet shortly.  I assume that there's pressure sensitive styluses out there that will work on all/most android devices? thanks!
afaik yes, it should work with every stylus! however you get the most out of it when you have a tablet that also transmits pressure sensitivity data to the pc!

title: Delivers
comment: Works great, especially if you have an active stylus.  Would be nice if I could choose absolute or relative positioning.

title: just what I was looking for
comment: Very nice way to use those old school artist abilities in the digital age.

title: Windows 8 x64
comment: Any chance for a driver or plug-in that will enable GIMP to listen for tablet device input?  Great idea for app.

title: Works as advertised
comment: Works great, only usefull thing I can think of to add is a wakelock.

title: Lifesaver!
comment: This app is great if you can't afford a drawing tablet for your computer and the best part is it emulates pressure sensitivity on non pressure sensitive devices!

title: Nice btw
comment: I can see this app really nice. But you guys have to find developer for windows and mac drive. It can be useful to all.

title: Wow
comment: I can't believe this is free. Absolutely brilliant programming!

title: GfxTablet
comment: Very useful! Works great with Ubuntu. At the same time interesting for those willing to learn more about drivers.

title: Works great, but needs configuration update
comment: This works perfectly on my TF101, and on my Sensation/Pyramid, but I have one small gripe -- there's no option for left-handed users so each time I tap, I get the right-button context menu, not the left click, so I then have to switch the mouse buttons on my Linux to use this app. Also agree with Fenix Kane, having a display feedback would be great, but expect it would slowdown the app.

title: Works great
comment: Worked flawlessly on my Nexus 7. The only feature I could hope for in the future is the ability to have it stream my desktop back so I can draw/edit directly on the tablet while still being able to leverage the power of proper desktop tools, enabling it to act as a Drawing Display like a Wacom Cintiq.

title: Love the idea
comment: Just too bad i know NOTHING about compiling software any chance of a .deb file in the future?

title: Lack of OS support
comment: Doesn't support Windows or Mac, seems to only support 64 bit Linux.

title: Wireless Waving tablet
comment: Turns your Note 10.1 into a proper wacom tablet!

title: Fantastic App, Awesome Developer
comment: I have a Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 and this app runs like a dream. This is a huge help with GIMP. And I recommend it highly.  I also want to mention the excellence of the developer. I was having a lot of trouble getting the driver on my computer (I'm a Linux noob trying to compile my first driver) and he(?) Emailed back and forth with me for over a week to make sure that I got the app running. That is true dedication from a free app. Thank God for open source!

title: Amazing.
comment: This app is a testimony to the wonders that open-source tech brings about.   Excellent job on enabling greater functionality in our tablets. Hats off to you guys!

title: Great start
comment: Works as advertised. Using Nexus7, so no pressure sensitive pen, but the app "fakes it" nicely by measuring contact area. So applying more finger area, or harder pressure with a rubber stylus (squishing the tip so there's more contact area) results in Gimp reading higher pressure. Experiment with pen Dynamics settings in Gimp to get different results.  Takes some getting used to, since there's no visual feedback on the tablet. Pen placement is thus an art in itself.  Would be mindblowing if future versions included some form of visual feedback on the tablet screen too. 4 stars for what it can do now - will edit later when the app matures with features.
